body:
This is an expected behavior because the resizing of web contents is asynchronous to the resizing of window, you can also observe the same behavior in Chrome and IE. Though on a fast computer the clipping would be hard to notice.

I'm closing this as won't fix because this is by design.

**Is it possible to not show the chrome at all, if the frame option is set to false?**

As the chrome shows when the app first loads for about a second until the HTML overlays it.... regardless of resizing the window and computer performance affecting the clipping, the chrome should at least be completely hidden rather than just covered up!

I can't believe that the above screenshots are considered acceptable as they look really unprofessional and as though the application is badly written... in fact a client noticed it straight away when we tried to demo the concept of using atom-shell for a native application.
I didn't notice that window chrome was also shown, this should be something that we ought to fix. What's the version of your Windows?

Yes, if you look at the first screenshot you can see an example of the window chrome showing even though the frame is set to false. You see this when a window first loads (and subsequent windows opened via BrowserWindow after app load), and when resizing the windows.

If you do a fix, I'll be happy to test it. Thanks.
How is this progressing?
I'm going to look into this one in just a few minutes.

Unfortunately I cannot reproduce this behavior on my Windows 8.1 system using Atom-Shell 0.19.1. I wanted to at least reproduce it there before i checked if the windows style change that was recently committed fixed this.
@frankhale Try Win7, Windows 8 doesn't have much window chrome at all
Yeah, I don't currently have access to a Win 7 machine. I'll see if I can find one.

@frankhale The easiest way by far is to hit up https://www.modern.ie/en-us/virtualization-tools#downloads and grab a Win7 VM from there - they're timebombed, but it should give you enough time to figure this out

I'm silly. I was able to locate a Win 7 machine rather quickly and was able
to confirm at least in my test the windows style change that was recently
commited has not resolved this particular issue. I can definitely see the
Windows 7 window border underneath the frameless window when I am resizing.
I'll dig in and see what I can find out.

On Wed Nov 12 2014 at 12:45:22 PM Paul Betts notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @frankhale https://github.com/frankhale The easiest way by far is to
> hit up https://www.modern.ie/en-us/virtualization-tools#downloads and
> grab a Win7 VM from there - they're timebombed, but it should give you
> enough time to figure this out
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/734#issuecomment-62759872.
@paulcbetts, thanks for the link. I'm definitely going to grab one of these images. It'll just be easier that way.

So does the latest window style change that was recently commited make the window border underneath the frameless overlay go away? Yes and No. 

Keep in mind these are only from my tests. Your mileage may vary.

Windows 8.1 - Yes, you cannot see anomalies when resizing.
Windows 8.1 high contrast theme - Yes, you cannot see anomalies when resizing.
Windows 7 with basic theme (non Aero) - Yes,  you cannot see anomalies when resizing.
Windows 7 with classic theme - Yes, you cannot see anomalies when resizing.
Windows 7 with Aero - No, you see the border underneath if your eyes are really fast or your machine is really slow. I still find it hard to see on the Windows 7 machine I have access to. It is definitely noticeable if you know what to look for.

NOTE: using Atom-Shell 0.19.1 a frameless app crashes on Windows 7 with a basic theme (non Aero) as well as Windows 8.1 using the high contrast theme. If you built from master it will not crash as far as I can tell.

I don't know yet if there is a window style that will be the fix for all situations. I'll keep digging.
Cool, seems like some good progress here. How's the fix for Win 7 with Aero going? Any more progress? Really excited to see this get fixed. Thanks.

I am going to continue to work on the Win7 Aero border issue today.

On Thu, Nov 13, 2014, 05:17 iamdriz notifications@github.com wrote:

> Cool, seems like some good progress here. How's the fix for Win 7 with
> Aero going? Any more progress? Really excited to see this get fixed. Thanks.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/734#issuecomment-62869487.

I'm making progress on this but it's going to take a little more time. I can make the border go away that is showing underneath the frameless window when resizing on Win7 with Aero but not without causing other side effects or doing it in a way that is not idiomatic. I'm going to try to wrap this up tomorrow if I can.
Okay I think I've solved this with no side effects. I want to sleep on it and then give it a sanity check in the morning. I'll update with the results then. Good night guys!
Can you post when an EXE is available to test with?

Okay. All seems well with my patch to resolve the Win7 Aero border painted on resize when window is borderless. I've tested on Win 7 with Aero, Win 7 VM with Aero, Win 7 without Aero, Win 2008 Server and Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 tech preview. Those other OSes were to check to make sure bad things didn't happen.

I just submitted a PR for this. To be on the safe side it'd be nice if somebody could test this on their own to see if it's okay.
How long before we can get a pre-built binary of this?
@iamdriz, I could post a snapshot of master with this patch applied to my OneDrive and then share it with you. In order for me to do that I need an email address to share it with.

@iamdriz, the PR would need to be accepted by Atom-Shell staff and then it'd be up to them when to release a new version of Atom-Shell. I don't think we should mess with that process, instead I can either share a compiled snapshot with you or you can build my fork yourself.

Here is the code:

https://github.com/frankhale/atom-shell/tree/win-aero-borderless-resize

If tools are a problem you probably have already heard that Microsoft released Visual Studio 2013 Community Edition for free.
cameron@driz.co.uk

Okay I shared a compiled snapshot of master with this patch applied. I'd like to make a note that even with the Aero border resize fix you'll probably still see an Aero Glass window underneath when resizing. I'd also like to point to @zcbenz comments earlier:

"This is an expected behavior because the resizing of web contents is asynchronous to the resizing of window, you can also observe the same behavior in Chrome and IE. Though on a fast computer the clipping would be hard to notice."

Clipping I can understand due to the aforementioned statement. But the chrome should be completely invisible for a frameless window! What does your patch do then if you can still see it??

Sent from my iPhone

> On 14 Nov 2014, at 16:57, Frank Hale notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> Okay I shared a compiled snapshot of master with this patch applied. I'd like to make a note that even with the Aero border resize fix you'll probably still see an Aero Glass window underneath when resizing. I'd also like to point to @zcbenz comments earlier:
> 
> "This is an expected behavior because the resizing of web contents is asynchronous to the resizing of window, you can also observe the same behavior in Chrome and IE. Though on a fast computer the clipping would be hard to notice."
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
My patch removes that border you see when resizing the window in Aero as per your screenshot above.
PR closed, After further testing it seems the border in Aero on the underlying window is coming back when resizing if the window is minimized and then restored.

To be fair this isn't only a Win 7 Aero issue. I can see the same issue on Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 Tech Preview. I've spent the entire day wrapped up in this and am quite familiar now with what is going on. The window styles set on the top level window need to be there so that window minimization and maximization animations happen like on a normal window. Among other things...

It looks as though the browser window or more importantly the content view or whatever it's name is that Chrome handles is set to extend into the non-client area of it's parent window. So when frameless you only think it's frameless. The frame is hidden from view and underneath the content view. Resizing that frame and CPU lag and asynchronous aspects of Chrome allow you to peek behind that window to see what is beneath. 

I'm not completely done trying to fix this. Apparently some magic with hooking into the WndProc of the top level window can be done to force the borders and controls to not paint there by giving us what we want. I'm currently going down this road but my first attempt last night and the PR this morning was not correct.
Chrome hosted app (formally packaged app) also has support for frameless windows, I think we can check how they fixed this. Though I don't know whether they had the same bug.
How's this bug progressing?

@iamdriz, I've pretty much done all I can do for this one. The way frameless works as far as I can tell is not at all to turn off window decorations on Windows but rather to extend the client area into the non-client area there by hiding the titlebar, minimize, maximize and close buttons. Resizing windows from the left edge seems to expose the controls underneath as the CPU tries to keep up with all the repainting. There are real trade offs by setting the Window style to eliminate these controls and it creates real problems and we lose functionality (as noted above). 

My guess is that we are going to need more crazy Win32 code in order to provide the illusion that those controls aren't actually underneath the frameless window.
@frankhale Not really sure what the outcome of this one is... Is this unfixable then?

I don't know if it's unfixable. Maybe some tricks can be done to make the controls underneath not paint but that requires hooking into the WndProc and I couldn't get it to work. I couldn't get the hook to work so could not investigate tricking the paint messages. I spent a very long time trying to make it work, several days.
Some news? Maybe we can see on how it implemented in NW.js? NW doesn't have the same glitch :pensive:
I'm using NW.js 0.12.3 with transparecy turned on, the side-effect disappears.

I'm closing this as won't fix since it is impossible to fix this without side effect.

There are basically two types of windows on Windows, one is window with frame (which has `WS_THICKFRAME` and `WS_CAPTION` styles), one is pure frameless window (which doesn't have those styles), Electron uses the former type for frameless window, that's why there is chrome showing when resizing window.

Does removing `WS_THICKFRAME` and `WS_CAPTION` styles work? We used to remove those styles, but then there were new problems, like there is no animation when minimizing and maximizing window, and maximized window will cover the taskbar. Basically if one window doesn't have `WS_THICKFRAME` and `WS_CAPTION` styles, Windows will not treat it as normal window.

But there is still work around, after setting `backgroundColor` for `BrowserWindow`, the chrome will be covered with the background color, which is not perfect, but should have solved this problem,

[edit]
had missed that this does not happen if transparency is on. Sorry. Will revisit if this re-occurs with transparency on a modern windows OS.
[/edit]
we need to fix this (We find this very visible in our particular UI) and may be able to spare some dedicated resource to make a PR.
would it be an option to pass something down with BrowserWindow thats says "I don't care about animations when resizing and the title bar being covered when full screen" so that `WS_THICKFRAME` and `WS_CAPTION` can be left off ? Is the problem that this has to happen globally and can't be window dependent?
Would it help if we investigated how nw.js manages to solve this problem?
@lukeapage I'm good adding an option for it.

I've been looking into this to see if I can make @lukeapage's use case viable. In particular, I'm just interested in disabling `WS_THICKFRAME` (and `WS_CAPTION`).

I'm a little unsure about removing the window styles. From [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms632600%28v=vs.85%29.aspx):

> After the window has been created, these styles cannot be modified, except as noted.

Unfortunately, `WS_THICKFRAME` (aka `WS_SIZEBOX`) has no exception, and using Spy++ I see that `WS_THICKFRAME` remains despite our attempted removal. So I imagine we need to modify the initial call to `CreateWindow`. 

This led me into `GetAcceleratedWidget()`, which leads into libchromiumcontent/brightray (via `views::Widget`). Building in debug mode brings down libchromiumcontent, and a `grep` on this doesn't show any CreateWindow calls, although admittedly this may not find CreateWindow calls inside pre-compiled libraries.

At this stage I don't know enough about libchromiumcontent or its dependencies to know if it's possible to create a window in electron without `WS_THICKFRAME` - I assume this is how NW.js handles it? If there's anything I've missed or existing API to create a window without the `WS_THICKFRAME` style, I'd be interested in knowing about it, although I imagine without providing the plumbing through to the window creation, this can't really be done?

Strange - this from nw.js: https://github.com/nwjs/nw.js/issues/3108
Seems to imply it can be removed but not added..
And @zcbenz says they used to be removed.. is it possible you are missing something?
And i know its not the source of truth, but this so artical suggests it can be removed afterwards: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2398746/removing-window-border
We recently have added the `thickFrame` option which can be used to create window without `WS_THICKFRAME` style.
Thanks, I missed that.
